list_definition.definition: to (cause to) spring or jump back from a solid surface

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She was bouncing a ball against the wall
The children were bouncing up and down on a trampoline.

list_definition.mean_english: bị trả về cho người ký vì không có tài khoản
list_definition.definition: (of a cheque/check) to be sent back unpaid, because of lack of money in a bank account

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I tried to pay his cheque/check into my bank account, but it bounced.

list_definition.definition: (of a ball etc) an act of springing back

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: With one bounce, the ball went over the wall.
There was a new bounce in his step.

list_ex_of_english: If he is wearing a safety helmet, he might not be bounced over the side.
She is certainly larger than life, and bounces around the stage.
Ambient illumination models the reflection of ambient light, which arrives at the object after being bounced in multiple reflections from the objects of the scene.
A wave-like pattern then becomes established downwind of the mountain range, with the air ' bouncing ' between the surface and the stable layer above.
Bouncing legislation through without due consideration is not the best way to form it.
The dispute bounces around various institutions, with no definitive resolution.
The toy object bounced each time the puppet moved the spoon, and only when the puppet moved the spoon.
Echo might be single or multiple, depending on how many times the sound bounces.
